Award.AwardTitle: New Stereoselective Fragment Coupling Reactions for Organic Synthesis
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this New award, the Chemical Synthesis Program supports Professor Regan J. Thomson of Northwestern University in an investigation of new reactions that enable the coupling of two or more molecular fragments to generate new molecules with specific molecular shapes. These reactions will be especially powerful within the realm of drug discovery, and ultimately facilitate the rate at which new biologically active entities can be prepared for further evaluation. These studies will expose students to a diversity of research areas including synthesis design, catalysis, methodology development, and the use of mass spectrometric techniques to screen products. The undergraduates and graduate students participating in this project will be involved in mentoring the research projects of Chicago area high school students.

The project will study new carbon-carbon bond forming reactions utilizing N-allylhydrazones and N-sulfonylhydrazones. The approach will involve the oxidation of allyl hydrazones to diazoallenes, which then undergo a stereoselective [3,3]-rearrangement with the formation of a new carbon-carbon bond ultimately producing carbocations, which can be trapped with external nucelophiles. In addition, sulfonyl hydrazones will be utilized in new carbon-carbon bond forming reactions. These stereoselective fragment coupling reactions will be employed in the systhesis of biologically active natural products.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of this award was to discover and develop powerful new stereoselective fragment coupling reactions that will have broad utility in organic synthesis. The outcomes of this NSF funded research “New Stereoselective Fragment Coupling Reactions for Organic Synthesis” included the development of new methods for the synthesis of complex organic molecules relevant to the preparation of pharmaceuticals and materials. Specifically, the chemistry developed allows efficient access to classes of compounds that are otherwise challenging to prepare directly using prior techniques. Many established synthetic methods produce molecules that are flat and lack three-dimensional complexity, whereas the methods developed during the course of this research afford compounds that possess a higher degree of complexity. In many cases, such molecules are known to possess enhanced and desirable properties with respect to drug development for treating human disease. We demonstrated the utility of these new methodologies by using them to synthesize numerous biologically active small-molecules through routes that were shorter and more efficient that those reported previously, thereby establishing significant intellectual merit to the research activities. The broader impacts of our study include new insights into fundamental reactivity of small organic molecules, the development of new classes of catalysis capable of generating complex structures efficiently, and access to novel bioactive molecules as potential drug leads.
